metadata.title: Properties of Nuclear Reactions Between Hydrogen Isotopes from R-Matrix Calculations

abstract.text: We discuss properties of nuclear reactions (branching ratios, reaction eonstants, etc.) between hydrogen isotopes from the standpoint of recent R-matrix calculations. These caleulations predict, for example, quite different branching ratios for the d+d reactions when they are initiated by S-waves than when they are initiated by P-waves. We will also give a more speculative discussion of the constraints on possible non-radiative elecromagnetic transitions that could occur for the d-d and p-d reactions in the metal latice.

When R-matrix theory is used to include nuclear effects at small distances in the ealculation of fusion rates, the rate expression exhibits a more complex interplay of the short-ranged (nuclear) and long-ranged (screened Coulomb) forces than does the familiar separable form,

to which the R-marix expression reduces if the appropriate approximations are made. Using the latest nuclear R-matrix infonmation for the d+d and d+t reacions in this more correct formulation, we have calculated rates for a variety of screened Coulomb potentials. The fusion rate calculations are presented as a function of the screening radius at fixed relative energy, and as a function of relative energy at fixed screening radius. They are compared with ealculations made using the standard expression above.
